Look, this game is the tits if you're into Neill Blomkamp, but it falls short like a lot of his projects do. The gameplay is fun, the visuals are amazing, the augment system has a lot of variety. The problem is that they took all these cool concepts and crunched it into (what was) an Epic Store exclusive with NFT elements in an already hyper-saturated BR market. There's definitely a feeling of "studio/artist vs corporate boardroom" in the mix, which kind of makes it a bit jumbled and unfocused. Not to mention the game's playerbase is rather sparse, there are definitely some matches where I feel like I'm playing against really badly coded bots. 

There's so much cool stuff going on here, and has all the workings of a great core game loop. However, I feel like this game has been effectively kneecapped by poor management and marketing. The actual meat-and-potatoes are solid, but I have a feeling something like this could have worked really well as a single player game with a larger scope, or perhaps even an extraction shooter (which I'm sure they're trying to shoehorn in to keep up with the kids). Either way, I'm still having a blast playing it, no matter how annoying that announcer is.

Marketplace Manipulation:

Off the Grid starts strong — the third-person battle royale offers solid mechanics, smooth controls, and fast-paced gameplay that instantly hooks you in. My first handful of matches were buttery smooth with no connectivity issues, likely because the lobbies were filled with bots. Still, the experience was fun enough to make me want more.

Unfortunately, once the game decided I was ready for the real competition, things went downhill. I started getting matched with what seemed like full squads, and while that challenge was welcome, the sudden drop in performance was not. Lag spikes, sluggish controls, and occasional unplayable matches quickly soured the experience.

There’s a great game hiding under the hood here — one with the potential to stand out in the genre — but until the connectivity issues are ironed out, Off the Grid feels like a missed opportunity rather than a daily go-to.

Off the Grid starts strong — the third-person battle royale offers solid mechanics, smooth controls, and fast-paced gameplay that instantly hooks you in. My first handful of matches were buttery smooth with no connectivity issues, likely because the lobbies were filled with bots. Still, the experience was fun enough to make me want more.

Unfortunately, once the game decided I was ready for the real competition, things went downhill. I started getting matched with what seemed like full squads, and while that challenge was welcome, the sudden drop in performance was not. Lag spikes, sluggish controls, and occasional unplayable matches quickly soured the experience.

There’s a great game hiding under the hood here — one with the potential to stand out in the genre — but until the connectivity issues are ironed out, Off the Grid feels like a missed opportunity rather than a daily go-to.
